extendedContent.title: Description and Nature
extendedContent.content:
The Sword of Nuada, known as Claoimh Solais (the "Sword of Light"), is one of the Four
                    Treasures of the Tuatha De Danann. Brought from the mythical city of Findias when the
                    Tuatha De Danann came to Ireland, this sword was the weapon of their first king, Nuada
                    Airgetlam ("Silver Hand").
                
                
                    The sword's most terrifying property was its inescapability: once the sword was drawn
                    from its sheath, no enemy could flee from it, and no one could resist its deadly stroke.
                    As a blade of pure light, it represented justice and righteous warfare, the legitimate
                    violence of the king in defense of his people.

extendedContent.title: Nuada and the Four Treasures
extendedContent.content:
King Nuada
                
                    Nuada was the first king of the Tuatha De Danann in Ireland. During the First Battle
                    of Mag Tuired against the Fir Bolg, he lost his hand and had to relinquish kingship,
                    as Celtic law required a king to be physically perfect. The physician-god Dian Cecht
                    fashioned him a silver hand, but he was not restored to kingship until Miach (Dian
                    Cecht's son) gave him a hand of flesh.
                

                The Four Treasures United
                
                    Together, the Four Treasures represented complete sovereignty over Ireland:
                
                
                    Stone of Fal: Legitimacy - screamed under the true king
                    Sword of Nuada: Justice - from which none could escape
                    Spear of Lugh: Victory - which never lost a battle
                    Cauldron of Dagda: Prosperity - which satisfied all
